chapter.title: About This Document
chapter.para: The purpose of this handbook is to facilitate deployment of &PRODNAME;'s rate limiting component. This handbook is not a tutorial. It provides basic information that will help you understand and deploy this &PRODNAME; component, but you must adapt this information to suit your own configuration.
This handbook is focused on one &PRODNAME; component. Other &PRODNAME; components are documented in companion handbooks.

section.title: Document Change History
section.para: This version of the handbook replaces and obsoletes all previous versions. The most recent changes are described in the table below:

chapter.title: Introduction to the Rate Limiting Component of &PRODNAME;
chapter.para: Rate limiting controls the flow of traffic. You can use &PRODNAME;'s rate limiting filter to manage the flow of traffic into your service so that it does not exceed the service's actual capacity. In addition to allowing you to manage legitimate workloads, this allows you to prevent overload due to abuse of your system.

To understand how &PRODNAME; handles rate limiting, you must understand the relationship between &PRODNAME; and an origin service. An origin service is the service for which &PRODNAME; is performing a function. For example, if &PRODNAME; is used to provide rate limiting to a load-balancing service, then the load-balancing service is &PRODNAME;'s origin service. Requests are sent to &PRODNAME; as the proxy for the origin service, not to the server where the origin service lives. &PRODNAME; functions as a reverse proxy, in that it acts on behalf of the origin service rather than on behalf of the client. &PRODNAME; passes client requests to the origin service only after those requests have been examined and processed by the &PRODNAME; filters configured for that origin service.

&PRODNAME;'s rate limiting filter protects the origin service from being bombarded by client requests. It accomplishes this by specifying limits for the number of times a client may request a given resource. When a client has exceeded the number of requests permitted during the current time period, no further requests from that client are delivered to the origin service until a new time period begins. This provides essential protection to any public-facing API.

A client's current limits may include the client's absolute limits. Absolute limits are specific to a service domain and are therefore only provided by the origin service. However, &PRODABBREV; will integrate absolute and current limits as they apply to a client.
&PRODABBREV; does not enforce absolute limits, but it does inform the origin service of those limits. You can learn more about absolute limits at .

The &PRODNAME; rate limiting component performs two categories of behavior:
querying for limits
tracking limits

tip.para: Rate limits are controlled by rate-limiting.cfg.xml; to change your rate limiting configuration, edit rate-limiting.cfg.xml. You can see an annotated example of rate-limiting.cfg.xml in .

chapter.title: HTTP Message Requirements
chapter.para: To correctly rate limit a requested resource, the rate limiting component uses one required HTTP header precondition and one optional HTTP header precondition.

td.para: X-PP-User is a single-value header. This header is used to describe the unique name of the client making the request. This name is used in part to cache and store request hits.
X-PP-Groups is a list of string values. This header is used to describe all of the limit groups the client belongs to. A client may belong to multiple limit groups or to none.

chapter.para: These headers are used by the rate limiting filter but are populated by other &PRODNAME; components such as the authentication filter.

&PRODNAME; filters may add values to HTTP message headers to communicate a set of options to downstream filters. To aid downstream filters in selecting the most qualified value from a given set, the values themselves may be annotated with a quality factor parameter. This allows downstream components to make a decision based on the available options rather then on which component overwrote the header last.

tip.para: To learn more about &PRODNAME;'s authentication filter, read about Client Authentication in our wiki or read the Repose Auth-N & Auth-Z Components Deployment Handbook.
To learn more about quality factors in HTTP message headers, read about Header Value Quality in our wiki.

chapter.title: Configuration

tip.para: Before attempting to customize your rate limiting configuration, familiarize yourself with the basic &PRODNAME; concepts and deployment methods in our Getting Started document.

chapter.para: The rate limiting component obtains its configuration, including its API endpoint, from a file named rate-limiting.cfg.xml. We have included an annotated example of a valid rate-limiting.cfg.xml in this section.
To change your rate limiting configuration, edit rate-limiting.cfg.xml at any time. Within rate-limiting.cfg.xml, you can specify the following:

table.caption: Customizable Elements of the Rate Limiting Configuration

tr.td: Endpoint: <request-endpoint> sets the endpoint and format with which the user can query limits.

<uri-regex> is a regular expression (regex) for the URI at which the user can query their limits. Within the regex, each capture group is allowed the number of hits specified in the value attribute of the limit element. For example, suppose the configuration specifies a regex of /v1/(.*) with value set to 100. With this configuration, some requests come in with a URI of /v1/pan and other requests come in with a URI of /v1/cake. Each user would be allowed 200 hits if the hits are evenly divided among the two URIs: 100 hits for URI /v1/pan and 100 hits for URI /v1/cake.
<include-absolute-limits> enables or disables integration with absolute limits.
<limits-format> identifies the format of returned rate limits.
OPENSTACK, the format supported by OpenStack. You can learn about this format at http://docs.openstack.org/api/openstack-compute/2/content/ProgramaticLimits.html.

<id> is the unique identifier for a given limit group

Key elements of the preceding example are labeled with callouts and explained below:

callout.para: The request-endpoint configuration element must specify a regular expression that identifies client requests for the client's current limits.

The uri-regex attribute of the request-endpoint configuration element must be a regular expression. It should match all representations of the request resource that the rate limiting component should answer.
The include-absolute-limits attribute of the request-endpoint configuration element is a Boolean attribute that can be used to switch on or off integration with the origin service's absolute limits.
One or more specifications of limit-group may be associated with a single specification of request-endpoint.
Limit groups identify a group of related rate limits and bind them to a series of names. The names can be used to limit incoming requests using the X-PP-Groups header.
An id uniquely identifies each limit-group.
Specifying groups for a limit-group associates it with recognizable workloads. In this example, one limit-group relates to customers and another relates to administrators.

A single limit-group may be identified as the default group. The default group will handle any requests that cannot be matched on the basis of a group name to any of the groups identified in the X-PP-Groups header. In this example, the limits defined for groups="customer" will be applied to requests that cannot be explicitly matched to a group.

section.title: Configuring Limits
section.para: To set a rate limit, assign acceptable values to the rate limiting configuration attributes as shown in the table below. You can see these attributes in context in the code sample introducing .

tr.td: The uri attribute of a given limit should be a human-readable representation of the regular expression used to match this limit. The URI is useful for client end-user interfaces as well as for documentation purposes.
The uri-regex attribute must be a regular expression and should match all request resource representations to which the given limit should apply.

Limits can trigger on specific HTTP methods. These trigger methods must be specified by the http-methods attribute. As the name implies, the attribute may contain more than one value; multiple values are delimited by spaces. The rate limiting component supports all valid HTTP methods as described by RFC 2616 at http://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc2616.txt. If the configuration specifies ALL for the http-methods attribute, this informs the rate limiting component that rate limiting should occur on all HTTP requests.
GET, DELETE, POST, PUT, HEAD, TRACE, OPTIONS, CONNECT, ALL

Every limit must specify a time unit specified by the unit attribute. The valid values for this attribute are also enumerated in the OpenStack limits XML Schema Definition (XSD) at http://docs.openstack.org/common/api/v1.0.

A limit's value attribute is an integer which describes the number of requests the limit allows. In combination with the unit attribute, the number of requests within a slice of time describes the rate for the given limit. The rate is then used to perform rate limiting.

important.para: The unit and value attributes must always be specified as pairs. For example, unit="SECOND" value="1" allows a rate of one request per second.

section.title: Constructing Cache Keys with Regular Expressions
section.para: The rate limiting component must be able to track rate limits per resource. To effectively facilitate this, the rate limiting component attempts to generate a cache key from the limit's regular expression, as defined in its uri-regex attribute. Extracting cache keys from the regular expression is performed via regular expression capture groups.

tip.para: Regular expression (regex) capture groups are essential in configuring the rate limiting component and other &PRODNAME; components. Our bibliography includes a link to an excellent source of information about regex capture groups.

section.para: If no capture groups are specified, then the entire request URI is used as a the cache key for the request. This is considered sub-optimal in most cases, since each unique resource representation will have requests made against it tracked separately.

The rate limiting component uses the java.util.regex package to match character sequences against patterns specified by regular expressions. The patterns are defined in java.util.regex.Pattern. You can learn about java.util.regex.Pattern at http://download.oracle.com/javase/7/docs/api/java/util/regex/Pattern.html.

warning.para: You can get an unexpected result by failing to account for all components of a request URI.

As you construct regular expressions, keep in mind that query parameters as well as other request URI components are included as part of the request URI that the rate limiting component operates against.

The rate limiting component cannot detect whether the service implementer is requesting that each resource request be tracked separately or as part of a group; the component defaults to tracking limited requests under unique keys.
This regular expression generates cache keys from the second-tier resource in a given request URI. This is useful for grouping child resources under a shared rate limit.

A service can require clients to use their account numbers as part of the resource tree to their service resources. For a client request formed like http://example.com/service/12345-account/resource, executing this regular expression against the client request extracts 12345-account. The rate limiting component can use this extracted information as a unique identifier to ensure that all of the recorded rate limits belong only to this client.

note.para: Service implementers should use capture groups in their regular expressions. In addition, the performance of the regular expression should be taken into consideration when designing limits. This is because a given expression's performance has a direct impact on the rate limiting component's performance and throughput.

chapter.title: Tracking Client Requests
chapter.para:
The rate limiting component uses the X-PP-User HTTP header for two purposes:
recording request usage on a per-limit basis
recalling all stored limits that belong to a named client

section.title: Cache Indexing
section.para: The caching format for the rate limiting component is designed for high throughput. Because of this, an aggregation index is required to group active rate limits for a named client.
The string value of the X-PP-User HTTP header is treated as the cache key for this index.

The rate limiting component indexes stored limit cache keys in a separate cached object for each named client identified with the X-PP-User HTTP header. This data structure is called the user limit key map.

section.title: Caching in Single-Node or Multi-Node Configurations
section.para: The rate limiting component caches in single-node or multi-node configurations.

The rate limiting component supports a single-node &PRODNAME; installation in which all cache operations are performed locally. When no other nodes are identified in the system model as hosting a distributed datastore component, &PRODNAME;'s default local datastore is used.
The rate limiting component supports multiple-node &PRODNAME; installations via &PRODNAME;'s datastore service. If a clustered datastore is available, the component will make use of it for caching.

chapter.title: Querying Current Limits
chapter.para: A client may ask the rate limiting component for information about the client's own current limits. Those limits may include absolute limits.

Valid content MIME types for such requests are:
application/xml
application/json
application/vnd.vendor.service-v1+xml
application/vnd.vendor.service;f=2;e=xml

As shown below, a request in which the user is identified via X-PP-User and the user's group is identified via X-PP-Groups generates a response showing all the limits applicable to that user in that group:

table.caption: Sample Request/Response Conversation: Request Limits for User

td.programlisting: GET /service/limits HTTP/1.1 Accept: application/vnd.rackspace-v1.0+xml X-PP-User: demo-username X-PP-Groups: demo-customer

chapter.para: The rate limiting component caches rate limits by user. Consequently, to query rate limits, a user must be passed into the rate limiting component. The rate limiting component uses the X-PP-User header to identify a user whose limits will be queried. Without a value in this header, the rate limiting component will send back a '401 Unauthorized'.

The rate limiting component uses the X-PP-Groups header to determine which rate limits to apply to the user. If this header is not present, the rate limiting component will assign limits from a default group specified in the rate-limiting.cfg.xml configuration file.

It is possible to query a user's rate limits before the user's limits are placed in the cache. This is the case when querying limits before the user has ever been rate limited. In this case, there are two possible results, based on the contents of the X-PP-Groups header:
If the X-PP-Groups header, containing specification of a group, is passed in, then the rate limits configured for the specified group in rate-limiting.cfg.xml are returned.
If the X-PP-Groups header is not passed in, then the rate limits configured for the default limit group in rate-limiting.cfg.xml are returned.

Once the user has made a call which uses any of the defined limits, the user has rate limits in the cache. At this point, the rate limiting component will return the limits stored in the cache for that user.

note.para: The rate limiting component understands quality factors for the X-PP-User and X-PP-Groups headers. This is useful when a service implementer wishes to employ multiple authentication/identity mechanisms. You can learn more about how &PRODNAME; handles authentication and identity in the &PRODNAME; Authentication and Authorization Components Deployment Handbook.

If multiple user or group values are present in the X-PP-User or X-PP-Groups headers with the same quality, then the first value is used. If the user or group does not have an explicit quality, &PRODNAME; assumes the quality for that item is 1.

chapter.title: Integrating Absolute Limits
chapter.para: The rate limiting component is designed to integrate with limits that are returned as a response from the origin service. These limits are absolute, meaning that they define limits for the service as a whole rather than for any individual consumer of the service. Absolute limits are specific to the origin service domain. For example, the absolute limits returned by the OpenStack Compute API may resemble the following:

table.caption: Sample Absolute Limits Returned by Origin Service

td.para: Maximum number of metadata items associated with a server

tr.td: Maximum number of metadata items associated with an image
Maximum number of file path/content pairs that can be supplied on server build
Maximum size, in bytes, for each personality file

chapter.para: To activate inclusion of absolute limits that are specific to a client's origin service, use the optional configuration attribute, include-absolute-limits.

When include-absolute-limits is set to true, the rate limiting component marks incoming requests that match the limit request endpoint's uri-regex and then passes them down to the origin service. After the origin service responds with the client's absolute limits, the rate limiting component enhances the response with the combined absolute and current rate limits. It then sends the response to the client.

note.para: Repose will always request absolute limits from the origin service as XML. This is due to issues with using XSL on JSON to combine absolute limits with current rate limits. After it receives the absolute limits response as XML, Repose combines the absolute limits response with the user's current rate limits and returns the combined limits in the media type (XML or JSON) requested by the user.

chapter.title: Handling Limited Client Requests
chapter.para: When a client makes a request that exceeds the client's specified rate limit, the rate limiting component will return the HTTP response code 413 (Request Entity Too Large).
When this occurs, the response's Retry-After HTTP header contains HTTP-encoded data that the client can use to plan a retry.

td.programlisting: GET /service/my/resource HTTP/1.1 Accept: application/vnd.rackspace-v1.0+xml X-PP-User: username X-PP-Groups: customer
HTTP/1.1 413 Request Entity Too Large Retry-After: Thu, 30 Jun 2011 20:24:39 GMT
